interlinear-text.item: GSK [Augures lies a la cuisson du pain] - [Briquet]

phrase.item: Omens linked to bread baking
The woman (wife) places the bread against the walls of the hearth (oven).
Everyone knows how we bake the bread.
When the woman places the bread up against the hearth (oven), a man sits near the orifice (opening) of the hearth or in the cavity in front of the hearth.
The woman takes the bread out of the hearth and this man makes it [the bread] golden (browns it by placing it on the embers inside the hearth)
Once all of the bread is cooked we give the last loaf to the man who browned the bread (made it golden).
He must share (split) this loaf between seven people.
‎‎If there aren't seven [people], he divides it between as many people as he wants.
We call this loaf "of the door."
There is a riddle about it: a sheep is on a slope and a wolf looks at her sideways.
If a part of the bread or the whole bread falls as we apply it against [the walls of] the hearth, we call it Wachk.
Tchakida is the Persian translation of Wachk (both being formed by a participle form of a verb to do with falling in the respective languages)
We say that it's once Saint Khizr walks through the door during the baking of the bead that "the bread bows it's head before him."
gujo = ?
This is why Wachk is considered to be sacred, we mustn't throw (give) it to the livestock.
It's all old stories (tales).
Now nobody eats it.
We give it to the livestock because it's stained with ashes.
Pottery
We dig up the clay. We bring it back and we grind it up.
When it has softened, we add goat wool to it.
Then we knead it, we mix it with water and we mold (form) containers.
It's used to make churns and large bowls.
Then we dry them and we smoothen them with a small round stone.
Next we bring dried manure and we put it in piles.
The heat that it gives off while burning makes the clay dishes turn red.
They are thus cooked.
Wool work
When sheep's wool is very long we shear it.
We shear it and the women spin it.
They make oakum and string.
Once it's transformed into string, they twist it.
Once it's twisted, they make yarn.
When the yarn is made, we take a loom
and we knot the frame.
Once the frame is knotted, we weave.
After the weaving, we wash, we cut (trim) and we sew a tchekmene.
Then we coat it. (?)
We shear the goat's wool and we clean it out (remove the straw from it?)
Then we spin it [the wool] and we weave carpets. (ploss: coarse wool carpets to cover the ground in the traditional home)
We work with yak wool in the same way. We clean it up and we spin it.
We also weave it into carpets. (ploss: coarse wool carpets to cover the ground in the traditional home)
Soap
We make the soap with saxaul
We burn it and get ashes.
We put them in a basket and we pour in water.
A solution seeps out.
Then we cook this solution, it thickens, and we get potash.
We cook this potash with butter to make soap.
Nowadays, there isn't any. (It doesn't exist - they don't use/make it anymore?)
Leather Finishing
The leather from large livestock, yacks, large goats, mouflons (bighorn sheep) are used to make boots.
We make the boots in the following manner.
First we prepare the skin with hot water, wheat flour, and salt.
After four to five days we remove the skin, we scrape it, we remove the hairs with a rock.
Next we treat it with nitrates (choura) and we stomp on it.
Shoora/shuura is the Persian for nitrate, cf. shoor/shuur "salty"
It [the skin/leather] "heats up", it will no longer be white and will no longer harden (become hard.)
We stomp on it with out feet on a stone.
After the stomping of the skin we take roots of yellow willow (a variety of willow), we bring them back and boil them.
The roots are red.
We mix them with the potash (same preparation as soap potash) or with poplar growths (outgrowths).
Next we rub it on the leather.
Next we boil the leather.
Once again we rub the leather with this mixture.
‎‎Next we boil the leather.
‎‎Once again we rub the leather with this mixture.
The deposit is called bedjeftcha.
Then once again we stomp on the skin, we coat it with melted butter and bone fat.
Bone fat comes from bones.
We take fatty sheep bones or bones from large livestock.
We grind them in a mortar.
Next we boil them and the grease that separates from the bone is called choudjrouv.
We rub it on the leather and we stomp on it once again.
The leather is fully penetrated with it, all the way through, the leather becomes supple.
The artisan cuts it up and makes boots.
Lighter
Before people made the flint out of steel.
By hitting it with quartz we get fire.
For this, tinder is also necessary.
We make tinder with sorrel.
We cut the stems, we dry them out and next we put them in a stew (we bury them in ashes and they become brown).
From the peelings we make tinder which catches fire rapidly.
Tinder is an equally good igniter.
As for the quartz, we say that during the night the stars burst all over and they release these ricks.
This is why we call them setorpoud (star tracks).
